captions.text:
Here's a vexing question asked at picnics
and beach parties everywhere: "Why do bug
bites itch?"
And the answer is: They don't.

Bug bites don't itch at all, sometimes you
don't even feel them, and that's pretty amazing

because what goes on under your skin when
a bug bites you is horrifying. Alright, some

insects, like certain kinds of ants, are venomous
so their bites can itch because their venom

contains formic acid, which can irritate and
blister the skin.

But let's talk about Nematocera, the suborder
of insects that includes black flies and mosquitoes.

These bugs have a long bendable proboscis
that they stick into you to drink your blood.

The proboscis is made up of six different
mouth parts. First you got the mandibles which

are hooked and the two maxillae which are
serrated like steak knives. These sharp bits

go as deep as they can to make an opening
for the other two mouth parts to pass through

-- the labrum and the hypopharynx. Those are
both long, hollow, flexible tubes and they

wriggle around inside of you like a worm while
the bug probes around for blood vessels.

Once it finds one, blood gets sucked up through
the labrum, and saliva is ejected down through

the hypopharynx. That saliva is an anti-coagulant;
it stops your blood from clotting inside the

bug's proboscis so that it can keep drinking.
It is also the main vector for diseases that

are transmitted by mosquitoes like Malaria
and West Nile Virus. And it has one other

awesome property: you are probably allergic
to it, and when you're allergic to something

your body produces histamine, the protein
that triggers inflammation and widens your

capillaries to allow white blood cells to
pass through them so that they can fight foreign
invaders.

So, it's the histamine that makes you swell
up and itch when you get a bug bite, just

like it makes your eyes and nose itch during
pollen season. We're not even sure why histamine

needs to make you itchy in order to do its
job. It might just be your body's way of telling

you that something's wrong with your skin.
But I'm pretty sure we all wish it would stop.

So thanks for asking, and thanks to all of
our Subbable subscribers who make this and

everything you see here on SciShow possible.
If you have a quick question that you'd like

us to answer, let us know. You can find us
on Facebook and Twitter and as always in the

comments below. And if you want to keep getting
smarter with us here at SciShow, you can go
to youtube.com/scishow and subscribe.

comments.text:
If white blood cells are sent to the bite area then why do we suffer from 
malaria or other diseases in the first place?? they would have got killed 
in the first place right??﻿
comments.author: Quazi Irtiza

comments.text:
People need to chill - unless you live in Africa or tropical places where 
mosquitoes carry diseases or botfly larvae there is no need to hate on 
those insects because their bite is actually beneficial.
When mosquito bites you it's saliva promotes your immune system to fight 
off foreign protein that is not lethal nor organs damaging. And when your 
immune system is frequently put at work like this you've a very good chance 
at becoming resistant to other severe diseases carried by ticks. And who 
knows, maybe even prevents you from developing other allergies if 
mosquitoes bite you during your childhood.﻿
comments.author: Karlis Liepa

comments.text:
which would make my comment not total bullshit. you said and I quote 
"People need to chill - unless you live in Africa or tropical places where 
mosquitoes carry diseases or botfly larvae there is no need to hate on 
those insects because their bite is actually beneficial" the U.S. is far 
from tropical or Africa and yet we have mosquitoes that are fully capable 
of carrying west nile and malaria(though it has no reported cases in the 
states). Please check your facts and your previous comments so that you 
don't contradict yourself.
comments.author: jake

comments.text:
+jake
Total bullshit. Where I live (N.europe) mosquitoes carry no diseases 
because people themselves don't carry viruses/bacteria that mosquitoes are 
capable of spreading.
And also the kinds of mosquitoes we have here are incapable of carrying 
certain viruses (forgot which ones) due to their anatomical differences 
compared to other siblings in different regions .
So in short - yes, there are areas where mosquito-spread diseases are 
non-existent.
comments.author: Karlis Liepa

comments.text:
+Karlis Liepa You don't have to be in any particular area to be affected by 
the diseases that mosquitoes carry. the cdc reported over 2000 cases in the 
U.S. of west nile, a low number(compared to total population) but far from 
nonexistent. and there are plenty of ways to help your immune system 
without a disease carrying insect biting you.

comments.text:
I think the reason why that we have crappy feelings when we get sick or 
bitten is so that your brain can tell you not to move around too much 
because when you move around a lot, not all of the energy is going towards 
the destruction of the foreign material in your body. If you were to lay in 
bed or sleep, the energy would stop being used for movement and thinking 
and instead would be used to destroy the invaders. Just a thought.﻿

landing on you.

comments.text: What is neurofibromatosis (or NF for short)?﻿
comments.author: Tiffany Wells

comments.text:
yep, tumors can grow anywhere on the nerves, and can cause, but rarely 
cancer.
comments.author: Tiffany Wells

comments.text:
oh and the tumors come from the glial cells ( a component of the nervous 
system)
comments.author: Kenny k

comments.text:
I know what neurofibromatosis is, I was hopping for scishow to do a video 
on it to raise awareness for it, but thanks for replying.
comments.author: Tiffany Wells

comments.text:
it's a medical condition it's causes are mainly genetic. its manifestations 
can go from a few dark spots on the skin (we all have dark spots that does 
not mean we suffer from NF. In NF those spots have a specific aspect) to 
non malignant (as in non fatal)  tumors growing anywhere in the body. Those 
tumors, even if not lethal, can, depending on their size and location cause 
malformations or abnormalities in the bones or disturb the functioning of 
the nerves or even obstruct the air ways which may lead eventually to 
death.  you can Google for images but be aware they are disturbing.

comments.text: This makes me very confused about anti-histamines. ﻿
comments.author: Amber Blocker

comments.text:
Not really. Allergens are in reality harmless. For example, cat dander does 
the body no damage, but some bodies recognize it as an invader, and thus 
release histamines which cause the allergic reaction, but they are not 
actually attacking anything dangerous. They're just making you miserable.
comments.author: Erin Hart

comments.text:
But, if histamines are released in the presence of an allergen to help 
(although they have a yucky side affect) wouldn't blocking them be kindof 
not helpful??
comments.author: Amber Blocker

comments.text:
Anti-histamines block histamines, thus preventing them from causing the 
allergic reaction.

comments.text:
Okay, but the Why question is pretty much glossed over here. Why, 
evolutionarily, do bug bites itch? I think even more interesting is the 
question of why healing scars itch and make us scratch them and tear them 
open again, exposing ourselves to more infection. There is so much in that 
reaction (common to all mammals at least) that is so dangerous from a 
Darwinian perspective that there has to be some good evolutionary reason 
outweighing the downsides. I have my own hunches. Anyone researching this?﻿
